ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MR TEH CHEANG WAN'S DRUG SUPPLY



    1. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs what attempts were made to find out how the late Minister for National Development Teh Cheang Wan obtained his supply of the drug with which he took his own life.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan died of an overdose of Amytal, a barbiturate.

    The Police, in the course of their investigations, interviewed the doctors who had attended to the deceased's health problems, and the pharmacist who had dispensed drugs to him previously. None of them said that they had prescribed or sold Amytal to him.

    Checks with the Ministry of Health revealed that it had stopped using the drug Amytal about a year before Mr Teh Cheang Wan's death. Mr Teh's wife and daughter also could not tell the police how and where he had obtained the drug.

Column: 1542



    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the stocks of all the suppliers of this drug were checked against their records?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I do not see that as a meaningful exercise and I do not think the Police did this, because they could go round checking all the pharmacies and what does it prove?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister not aware that under the Poisons Act, a strict record has to be kept by all those who stock this poison, showing the amount of stock in their possession, how much was released and to whom? May this House know whether a thorough check was carried out on all suppliers?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, this drug could be obtained anywhere in the world. It could have been obtained from outside Singapore. And if the Police were to be led, as Mr Jeyaretnam suggests, on a wild goose chase in checking all the drugstores, then it is really a waste of Police resources, unless Mr Jeyaretnam has information to show that indeed somebody actually prescribed him and gave him the drug that led to his suicide. Is he suggesting that?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Are we to understand from the Minister that no check was made on all the suppliers? May we also have an answer whether Mr Teh Cheang Wan returned to Singapore from abroad shortly before his death?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I am really puzzled by the sudden interest of Mr Jeyaretnam on this subject of how Mr Teh Cheang Wan got his drug more than 11 years ago. The Police had done all they could to determine how he got the drug by asking his doctors, his pharmacist and the people whom he could have obtained the drugs from. Unless the Member is able to give us some lead as to where the late Mr Teh got his drug, I am afraid that we will be on a wild goose chase, as Mr Chiam had led the House and the Commission of Inquiry on a wild goose chase many years ago.

Column: 1543

I do not know why Mr Jeyaretnam is interested in this question. I think nobody, other than the person who gave Mr Teh that drug or Mr Teh himself, would know where the drug came from. And even if that person who gave him the drug were to own up and say, "I am the one who gave", I do not think that can be corroborated because Mr Teh is already dead. So the only person who can really tell where Mr Teh got his drug from is Mr Teh. Maybe for those who are really interested in finding out where he got his drug from, I think that can be done one day when we leave this world. And if their path crosses that of Mr Teh Cheang Wan, ask him the question. Then their curiosity will be satisfied.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: May I have another supplementary question, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: All right, one last question.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: All right, Sir. Thank you very much. Let us have an unequivocal answer. Are we to understand that the Government made no check on all the suppliers and the Government was not interested in finding out?

    Mr Speaker: I think the question has been answered already. Mr Wong.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, I think Mr Jeyaretnam is really making it sound like there is something sinister and is insinuating that the Government is on a cover up for Mr Teh Cheang Wan. I think he would not have forgotten that many years ago when he made such a suggestion with his ill conceived remarks, he paid $260,000 for those remarks. Here, I have given him answers free of charge and he is still not satisfied.

SAFE WATER SUPPLY



    2. Mr Simon S. C. Tay asked the Minister for the Environment whether Singapore's water supply remains safe for human consumption and its coastal water safe for swimming and water sports following the recent chemical fire in Tuas.

Column: 1544



    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the recent fire in Tuas poses no danger at all to the safety of our water supply.

    The factory that was destroyed by fire on 7th March 1998 is located outside PUB's water catchment area. Water that was used to fight the fire was also discharged outside the water catchment area into the sea at the Northern Tuas Basin. The basin and the surrounding area are not used for swimming and other recreational activities. Nonetheless, as a precaution, we alerted the factories in the vicinity immediately to warn their workers not to use the water in the basin. We also issued a press statement on 7th March 1998 to advise members of the public to keep out of the area. By 9th March, the quality of the water in the Northern Tuas Basin had returned to normal.

    Sir, to protect our water resources, my Ministry requires industries that use or store hazardous chemicals to be sited in designated areas such as Tuas and the Jurong industrial estates, which are outside water catchment areas.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Sir, in view of the high concentration of chemical industries in that part of the island, I just like to ask whether there are special provisions to ensure that a major catastrophe would not contaminate our water around that area.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, even though these are designated sites, we have very stringent requirements in place. For example, at the building plan stage, my Ministry would have already checked and ensured that there are adequate measures such as containment facilities, leak detection and warning devices, emergency plans in case something happens. All these are ready at the planning stage, even before the building plans are approved. This is to ensure that in the case of any accident, we are able to limit the damage to the environment and the health threats to not just the general population, but to people working in the immediate vicinity as well.

    Question again proposed.

    Dr Ker Sin Tze (Aljunied)(In Mandarin): Sir, the Government does not allow single persons to buy flats directly from HDB. This is very unfair. Although two single citizens above the age of 35 can buy flats directly from the HDB, to have two unrelated persons buying a flat and living together harmoniously is a difficult task to accomplish. Even though they jointly apply for a new flat, they would not be able to get the same kind of subsidy granted by the Government to other citizens. If the argument against allowing a single person to buy a new flat is that it may be wasteful for him to live in a big flat all by himself, perhaps the HDB can restrict single persons to buying only 2-room or smaller flats. I would appeal to the Minister to allow single persons to individually buy a flat directly from HDB, and to give them the same kind of subsidy enjoyed by other citizens.

    Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, I join Dr Ker in making the same plea, because, presently, singles do not enjoy subsidised public housing unless they are aged 35 and above. They would then qualify for new flats under the Joint Singles Scheme. Singles do not find the current situation equitable and feel that they are discriminated against in the distribution of subsidies to Singaporeans.

    In a Straits Times' survey on 26th September 1997 on the attitudes of Singaporeans to public housing, 76% of the respondents believe that the Government should provide subsidies to

Column: 1546

singles to help them own HDB flats. Based on the 1995 general household survey, the number of single residents in the age group between 30 and 49 has increased from 69,000 or 3% of the population in 1980 to 184,000 or 6% of the population in 1995. In other words, in 15 years, it has doubled.

    As an aside, I would like to humbly point out that the Nominated MP, Madam Claire Chiang, in an earlier speech in this House, I believe, in the motion on tripartism moved by NMP Mr Cyrille Tan, said and I quote, "The 1990 Census Report reported that single parent family households comprise 60,999 households with widowed parents and 17,585 households with divorced parents, representing approximately 10% of all family-based households." Again, to put statistics into perspective, I would like to humbly point out that according to the Census Report of 1990, the number of heads of households who were widowed and divorced totalled 78,584 or 11.9% of total households. Out of these, 60,999 heads of households were widowed or about 9.2% of total households were thus single parent family households with widowed parents, as stated by Madam Chiang in her speech. In the same Census Report, there were 17,585 heads of households or 2.7% of total households who are divorced and not households with divorced parents, to quote Mdm Chiang.

    Anyhow, Sir, I join Mdm Chiang and Dr Ker to make this plea to Government to review this policy for singles as many Singaporeans who are affected find themselves disadvantaged.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Sir, first let me thank Members for raising several issues on public housing policies. Let me take first Mr Zainul Abidin's request for a report of the effectiveness of last year's policy review.

    The public housing situation is now stabilized. As at end February 1998, there were 128,800 applicants on the waiting list. Of these, 60,800 are first-timers and 68,000 are upgraders. Compared to

Column: 1547

February last year, we had 141,000 applicants. So the situation today is better than last year. The new applications received by HDB are now more sustainable. HDB now receives about 1,000 to 1,500 applications per month. This trend, if sustained, will bring the annual demand for new HDB flats to a more realistic level of about 20,000 per year compared with the 67,000 that we received in 1996. The number of applications under the fiance-fiancee scheme has also dropped to a more realistic figure of 500 a month, about half the monthly figures that we received in 1996. There were also more first time applicants than upgraders recently. This should be the case as first-timer applicants should be and are given higher priority in owning their first flats. The revised policies have led to an overall reduction in the waiting time for new HDB flats. First-timer applicants for 4-room and 5-room flats in the north and west zones will now be able to book a flat in approximately 2 years, those in the north-east zone within 3 years, and those in the Punggol 21 queue slightly over 3 years. Upgrader applicants in all zones will have to wait longer for their flats, about 3 1/2 years for the north and west zones, about 4 years for the north-east zone, and more than 5 years for the Punggol 21 estate. Applicants are allowed to transfer their applications to another flat type or zone and their applications will be set back by three months on the queue.

    The revised resale levy imposed in 1997 has also discouraged frivolous demand from upgraders whose existing flats are already able to meet their existing needs. Prior to May 1997, there were about 300 new applications received per month from upgraders who were already existing lessees or ex-lessees of 5-room flats or bigger. This number has now dropped to an average of 22 per month. The vast majority of upgrader applications now are applicants from 4-room or smaller flats. These applicants are our target group for upgrading to a second flat.

    So the measures have achieved what we set out to do. HDB is building 35,000 flats in 1998, 27,000 for first-timers and

Column: 1548

8,000 for upgraders. The waiting time for first-timers has shortened. We have weeded out the more frivolous demand. I would therefore say the overall impact of the 1997 revision in the policies has been positive.

    Let me now turn to the resale market for HDB flats as a backdrop to our subsequent discussion. Resale prices of HDB flats showed huge increases from 1993 to 1996. In May 1996, the Government introduced measures to curb speculation in the private residential property market. With the correction in prices for the private residential properties it is inevitable that HDB resale prices will also follow suit, especially for the top-end of the HDB resale market. A correction of prices at the top-end of the market will subsequently filter down to the smaller HDB flats. The 1997 HDB policy changes also curbed the speculative demand for HDB flats brought about by easy credit policy for HDB mortgage loans. This correction in the HDB resale prices is not unwelcomed, considering the huge increase in prices from 1993 to 1996. The correction has made resale flats more affordable. Upgraders who need extra living space or who want a flat fast can now consider buying flats from the resale market. For first-timers, they are assisted by a $40,000 CPF housing grant or $50,000 grant if they live near their parents. More and more first-timers are taking up the CPF housing grant to buy a resale flat.

    Let me now turn to pricing and affordability. Several Members have expressed concern that in the current economic downturn some HDB flat owners may not be able to afford HDB flats or they may face difficulties paying for the mortgage loans. I would like to reaffirm the Government's commitment to provide affordable public housing to Singapore citizens, especially first-timers and families in the lower income groups. As I have said several times, the Government's commitment is to price new HDB flats such that 90% of Singaporean households will be able to afford at least a 3-room flat and 70% at least a 4-room flat. This policy has not changed. In general, HDB flats are priced such that purchasers are able to pay their monthly loan instalments within

Column: 1549

the 30% limit of their monthly CPF contributions which can be used to pay for their housing. The cash outlay that flat applicants have to take out from their disposable income is minimal. HDB records show that in 1997 the average monthly loan instalment constituted around 25% to 30% of the gross household income of the purchasers. Also, 80% of purchasers were able to service their monthly household loans entirely from their CPF contributions. This proportion is very high considering that some purchasers are self-employed with no CPF contributions.

    A further proof that HDB flats are affordable is evident in the very low loan default rate. Last year, HDB recovered only 5 flats out of 430,000 flat owners with outstanding mortgage loans, arising from the purchasers' inability to service their monthly loan payments. To make sure that HDB flats remain affordable to Singaporeans even in the current economic conditions, we will monitor the affordability indicators very closely.

    Mr Zainul Abidin has raised concern about Government helping low income families own their flats. I can assure Members that MND would keep its eye on the ball and make sure that low income families continue to be able to afford HDB flats. In 1994, we announced four policies to allow them to do so: (i) the sale of rental flats to sitting tenants at a discount; (ii) sale of 3-room flats purchased by HDB from the open market and then sold to applicants, also at a discount; (iii) sale of smaller 4-room HDB flats; and (iv) priority allocation of 3- and 4-room flats to HDB rental flat tenants. These policies have been very successful and later on I will announce an extension of this programme.

    Mr Ong Kian Min asked about applicants or buyers who may have lost their jobs in the current economic turmoil and how HDB can help them service their loans. HDB has several measures to allow home buyers to reschedule their mortgage loans. First of all, we allow them to pay the mortgage loan arrears by instalments within a reasonable period. Secondly, we allow them to reschedule

Column: 1550

their loans up to the maximum repayment period that they are eligible for. Thirdly, we also allow those in hardship to defer payments of the loan instalments for an initial period of six months, and with a further extension of six months if their temporary difficulties continue. Fourthly, we can also convert their loan scheme to an easy repayment scheme. Under this scheme, the monthly instalment for the first five years is at 75% of the normal instalment amount. It is then recomputed from the 6th year onwards to the end of the repayment period, based on the outstanding loan on the 6th year. Finally, we also encourage the inclusion of a working family member as a joint owner so that the CPF monies of the new lessee can be used to pay for the arrears. Sir, I want to assure Mr Ong Kian Min that HDB would resort to recovering the flat due to loan default only as a last resort.

    Mr Ong also asked about applicants who may want to change to a smaller flat because of their difficulties. If applicants are unable to afford the flats they have booked because of financial difficulties, they can apply to HDB to cancel their applications or change their applications to smaller flats. On a case-by-case basis, depending on their circumstances, HDB will consider waiving the penalty fees for the cancellation and also the 3-month setback for the change of flat type.

    Mr Kenneth Chen has asked whether more first-timers are now applying for 5-room flats rather than smaller units and whether we should have some criteria to make sure they can afford to do so. As you all know, HDB has already implemented policies such as credit assessment to ensure that applicants buy flats within their affordability. The amount of loan HDB grants also depends on their age and household income and is capped such that the monthly instalments do not exceed 40% of the buyer's gross monthly income. With these conditions in place, there is therefore no need to impose further criteria for applicants of 5-room flats. We hope, and we encourage, all Singaporeans to buy within their means.

    Let me now turn to the issue of housing subsidies. The reason why HDB flats are

Column: 1551

affordable is because they are heavily subsidized. This question of public housing subsidy is a long-standing debate. It started in 1984 between Mr Chiam and the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan and continued in 1988-1989 between Mr Chiam and Mr S Dhanabalan. I assume Mr Chiam now understands housing policies and therefore we do not hear very much about this from him. But now we get a new "Chiam". Mr Low Thia Khiang wants to raise this debate.

    The most direct and the clearest manifestation of housing subsidy is the CPF housing grant of $40,000 for first-timer couples to buy a resale flat. This is the most direct subsidy. Furthermore, if the first-timer couple buys a resale flat within 2 km from their parent's flat they enjoy a higher grant of $50,000. In FY96, 4,692 first-timer families made use of this grant. A total of $203 million was disbursed. In FY97, based on current projection, the disbursement of CPF housing grant is estimated to go up to $223 million. This is the most direct form of housing subsidy.

    The extension of this CPF grant concept is the 3-room buy-back scheme. Here, HDB buys 3-room flats from the open market, pays the going market price and then sells the flats to applicants on the 3-room flat waiting list at a discount of up to $50,000. That is again a very direct form of housing subsidy. Since the scheme started in 1994, HDB has bought more than 7,500 3-room flats. The subsidy involved in this scheme amounts to about $375 million over the three years.

    Let me now turn to new HDB flats. There are 128,000 applicants on the queue. Why is that so? Because the subsidy is greater for those waiting for new flats than the $40,000 or $50,000 CPF grant. If the subsidy is less, then why wait so long in the queue? The Government's approach to pricing of HDB flats and housing subsidy is very clear. I have explained this many times. Let me reiterate the principles.
1.00 pm

    First, we will subsidise the smaller flats more than the bigger flats. Second, we

Column: 1552

will subsidise the less popular areas more than the popular areas. Mr Low Thia Khiang said that HDB made a development profit in the Sengkang contracts. This is no great revelation. I supplied those figures last month. For the bigger flats, especially the design-and-build flats in Sengkang, HDB made a development profit. In the Woodlands and Jurong West contracts, however, HDB made a development loss. Overall, HDB made a development loss of $280 million in 1997. If there is no subsidy, then why do we still have 40,000 applicants in the North-east queue waiting for flats in Sengkang Town? The reason is very simple. Because the average market subsidy of a new flat in Sengkang Town in 1997 was $103,000.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang gave these numbers, which were supplied in February. I hope he would take these numbers and publicise them in The Hammer. Publicise these numbers widely, tell all the Workers' Party supporters that the Government made a development profit in Sengkang and that therefore they should withdraw from the North-east queue. We have 40,000 applicants in the North-east queue. I assume the Workers' Party can command 10-20% of support from Singaporeans. So I shall look forward to perhaps 4,000 to 8,000 of Workers' Party supporters listening to Mr Low Thia Khiang, knowing that the Government made a profit and, therefore, withdraw from the North-east queue. If that happens, I will buy Mr Low a very good lunch.

    An hon. Member: Dinner.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Dinner! Would Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam object to him having dinner with a PAP member?

    If Mr Low wants to publicise these numbers further, I can help him even further. There are 1,400 constituents in Hougang Constituency who are on the North-east queue. HDB can provide a direct mailing list to these 1,400 applicants, tell them that Mr Low says that Sengkang flats are not subsidised, that the Government made a development profit and, therefore, they should withdraw from the queue.

Column: 1553



    Singaporeans are not stupid! They know whether there is a subsidy in HDB flats or not. Mr S. Dhanabalan took some pains to explain the concept of market subsidy to Mr Chiam. I hope Mr Chiam now understands the meaning of a market subsidy.

    The concept of market subsidy is nothing new. It is practised in Hong Kong. It is a very complicated system in Hong Kong. Let me just explain the gist of it. In Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Housing Authority sells a flat to the Hong Kong resident at a price. When they sell the flat, they estimate what is the market price of the flat that they are selling and, therefore, what is the price that they are selling, the discount of the flat that they are selling, compared to the market price. So if they sell a flat at, say, 35% discount of the market price - the market price is compared to the private property in Hong Kong - that 35% discount is levied when the Hong Kong residents sell their flats 10 years later. So when the Hong Kong Housing Authority sells you a flat, they tell you that this price is at 35% discount of the market price. You are not allowed to sell your flat until 10 years later. When you sell your flat 10 years later, they levy 35% on the market price.

    In Singapore, we do not do such a thing. We allow you to sell your first flat and you do not pay a levy. You only pay a levy if you re-enter for a second flat. We also allow you to sell after five years, not after 10 years. And when we talk about market subsidy in Singapore, we are comparing the price of HDB flats to the resale HDB price, not to the private property as in Hong Kong.

    So what does this all add up to? In the latest HDB's audited accounts for FY96, the deficit for sale of flats amounted to $1 billion. This comprises the development losses that HDB incurred from the sale of new HDB flats as well as the market discount for the sale of 3-room flats to low-income families. For FY97, the accounts are not audited yet, but HDB expects to incur a deficit of about $600 million for its sale of flats activity. As I said earlier, HDB incurred a development loss of about $280 million in 1997. HDB

Column: 1554

incurred $100 million in the buy-back of 3-room flats, and there is another $200 million of subsidies in CPF grants. All these numbers have been published in HDB's accounts since 1985. There is no great revelation in what Mr Low said yesterday. In fact, as I have offered, we will be happy if he publicises these figures and encourages the people to withdraw from the Sengkang queue.

    Let me now turn to CPF grant for the singles. This is an appeal made several times by MPs in this House. I am happy to announce that, with effect from 1st June 1998, the Government will extend the CPF Housing Grant Scheme to single citizens to help them purchase HDB resale flats.

    Single citizens who purchase a resale flat under this scheme will get a grant of $15,000. Joint singles who purchase a resale flat under the Joint Singles Scheme will get a grant of $30,000. Why $15,000? We feel that the singles should not have the same amount of grant as the first-timer couple. In fact, the grant should be less than half, and therefore we have pegged it at $15,000.
